critique: This executive order, issued in 1940, focuses on coordinating federal construction projects. It designates various federal entities as "construction agencies" and mandates them to prepare and submit long-term plans and reports to the Bureau of the Budget and the National Resources Planning Board. The order aims to facilitate advance planning and ensure alignment with the President's program. There's a clear emphasis on centralizing information and oversight of construction projects within the federal government. It is signed by the President, but the name is not included in the document. It is difficult to assess the ideological tilt, immigration approach, security vs. liberty, or social inclusion aspects based solely on this document. The order seems to expand executive power by centralizing control over construction projects and requiring agencies to align with the President's program. It also leans towards federal primacy by mandating federal agencies to report to central bodies. It also seems to involve government intervention in economic matters by coordinating and planning construction projects.
